content.body: TabAtkins, fixed.
Cool!
Other suggestions?
is minuting again.
AryehGregor: i wanted to ban <div>, too.
TabAtkins: jamesr was looking for you in #webkit. You might want to consider joining #chromium too.
hixie -  i just got your email re http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9160
Hixie: Thanks for the heads up.  Joined now.
Hixie: what about a multiple choice survey question (check all that apply)
that's the situation i'm interested in
what if none apply?
seems very dodgy to me to use checkboxes in that way
hixie: i'm a supplier of survey systems for restaurants
there are times when there's a multiple choice non-exclusive question that is required
like what?
i.e. what keeps you coming back? after someone has already said they dine frequently
that's exactly the kind of question where i'd hate for hte browser to force me to pick at least one
if the client insists that a question be required, i have to make it required
i can tell them why it's not worth requiring
but they pay for me
so much so that for similar questions in the past i've gone in with a DOM inspector and killed the JS that forces me to do it, and submitted it that way
i can force you to select one if it's mutually-exclusive
i should be able to do the same for multiple-select
Hixie: this isn't about form UI - it's about the API
i'm not saying that i like required survey questions
the API is about form UI
i don't think we should support this kind of UI
but there's a situation where you can require an input and it needs to be defined
e.g. what is a required checkbox
right now it is defined as "the checkbox has to be checked"
i don't understand how my proposal endangers yours
it doesn't
why would there be an input group if they weren't related?
so why should checkValidity only apply to that control
not the group, like with other grouped controls
because what you're proposing is bad ui
applying it to the group seems more consistent - easier to grok
it's no less bad than requiring a radio group to be checked
it would encourage people to make such interfaces
i agree, with radio buttons the mistake is allowing any to not be checked in the first place
unfortunately that boat has sailed
but required is essentially meaningless without applying it to the group
no?
it has a very well-defined meaning
thereis no "group" with check boxes
just checkboxes that happen to share a name
just like you can have many text input fields with the same name -- doesn't make them into a group
if you have <input type=text name=a required> <input type=text name=a required> you aren't required to type something into one or the other
in my mind, a checkbox is a type of radio that is mutually inexclusive
you're required to type something into both
which is why this is distinct from a text input
checkboxes and radio buttons are separate just like checkboxes and text fields
checkboxes are closer to radio than to text fields
i think thinking of them as similar is misleading and leads one to designing poor UIs
i really don't think that extending the wacky radio button required="" model to text fields makes any sense at all
anyway, is there even a concept of order in query parameters?
couldn't you have either Apt#B 123 Fake St and 123 Fake St Apt#B
depending on how the vendor parses it?
it's always sent in form order
or does A before B in the HTML mean A is before B in the query?
ok
so your counterpoint is that someone could have address as the name for both fields, and only want to require the first line?
and want the second line filled to not fulfill the first line's requirement?
since there's no way to know on the server side which was filled, i don't see why the requirement should affect text fields any differently than radios or checkboxes
if you have text boxes A B and C called address, and get two values for address on the server side
you don't know which two you got
you always know which one was filled in since you always get both, in the order they were in the form
but if B is empty, you don't get a key with no value
whether or not they were filled in
yes you do
really?
ok
my mistake
i'm less bothered by your opinion on the matter than that there is no discussion about it
i feel steamrolled
i'd really like to hear other people's POV on this, because I feel my original point remains valid
til: you can ask for an escalation -- see the boilerplate i posted in the bug for details on how to do that
i misunderstood.  i'm not used to being able to reopen my own bugs

well reopening just means you're asking me to reconsider -- if you want to escalate it to a working group issue that the chairs then decide on rather than me, you have to set some keyword or something
and then some elves come along and automagically raise the issue for you
(honestly not quite sure how that happens)
there's a link in the boilerplate i pasted that explains it iirc
i'm working on that now
k
i'm slow to respond because i'm typing in bugzilla :)
Hixie: thanks for the discussion
i've escalated the bug
hopefully we can get more input
Added IE9 IE9 http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-browser-stylesheets/table.php
How can I get tweet feeds on the page.
like a kind-of twitter widget that will show anything related to #iecss

http://www.iecss.com/ woot
JonathanNeal: interesting. I was unaware that IE had undergone unit category changes in the UA style sheet
hsivonen, between versions?  yes.
hsivonen: yes

hsivonen: it's filed in v.nu bugzilla
zcorpan: thanks. I just filed it as https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=555906 while I wasn't looking at IRC
notes that the Vodafone rep to the TAG still puts EXI as a bullet point on "mobile" slides
what is EXI?
the class='' recommendation on b and i doesn't make much sense
othermaciej: "efficient" binary compression representation for XML infosets
oh, that
bets OBML is more efficient than EXI
but maybe not a fair comparison since obml doesn't represent an infoset
zcorpan: is OBML what Opera Mini uses?
zcorpan: does it transfer the CSS box tree?
hsivonen: it's what opera mini uses
hsivonen: i don't know what it transfers exactly
zcorpan: ok
feature testing for structured clone in webworkers is similarly annoying
it would be easier if non-strings throwed from the start
gives up on trying to go to Glasgow
hsivonen: The answer for what OBML transmits is AFAIK "no comment" :)
gsnedders: I see. my css box tree guess remains
does anyone know which server is used for http://trac.webkit.org/browser/trunk/LayoutTests/websocket/tests
https://trac.webkit.org/browser/trunk/WebKitTools/Scripts/webkitpy/layout_tests/port/websocket_server.py ?
zcorpan: tyoshino or ukai will know
though they may be away
(21:11 in Japan)
hi
ukai should know well but he's not here now.
ok, thanks
basically you're right. we're using pywebsocket and some helper scripts
ok
I now got that attachment (indeed looks like a Word document), but I cannot open it...
Post it on the public web as a hacking challenge
Give extra credit for inventing a time machine to crack it before March 15th 2010
someone with Word can prolly win that contest within minutes
annevk: Delete a few bytes at random from the file, so Word will just report it as corrupted and fail
annevk: Still you get to find out what the file says
just got a reply with the questions inline
but no time machine :(
you guys watch too much tv
and mostly science-fiction at that it seems :p
It's strange how rarely science fiction focuses on technology problems like incompatible file formats
The problems are always stuff like engines exploding
Cowboy Bebop had an excellent take on that
They found a really old video tape they wanted to play, but it was betamax

Even with modern cars, it's pretty rare for the engine to explode and pretty common for the on-board computer to develop some kind of software fault, so presumably the same kind of thing will continue into the future
The only exception I can think of (with my not-very-good memory) is in Halting State, where some guy stays up all night writing Perl scripts to translate data between two slightly different databases
but then it's spoiled by having a computer that explodes later on
(if I remember correctly)
I wish iki.fi had shorter delays on DNS updates...
the server that hosts hsivonen.iki.fi changed its IP address without prior notice
hsivonen, did you change that 404'd PNG link ?
erlehmann: not yet. I intend to fix it once my personal site becomes usable again.
annevk: what's rumored to be in this Word file you've obtained?
Goodmorning :)
Timezoneist
in Japan, for people who work at bars and such at night, it's common to say おはよ (good morning) no matter what time of day it actually is
when first seeing somebody for the day
even if that happens to be 23:00 in the evening or whatever
what is Viognier?
hmm, Rhone valley
this could be good
looks around for the wine steward
MikeSmith: In Japan it it common for shop assistants to compete for who can say "Irashaimasen!" in the most whiny voice. Doesn't mean it's a good idea :)
heh
jgraham: that's why I wear earblugs
plugs
one unfortunate thing in Japan is that being enthusiastic sometimes (often) means being noisy
e.g., if you go to a baseball game, there is always this huge cheering section of people who do nothing but make noise for the entire game
I think most of them are not actually paying any attention at all to what is going on in the game
wow, this Viognier tastes somewhat like one of those chocolate oranges
Terry's Chocolate Orange
what's the viognier?
paul_irish: wine
white wine
hahah no i mean who is the vineyard. :)
oh
Gadino Cellars, Greene County, Virginia
apparently
I don't recommend it
unless you really like chocolate oranges

Oh tight. I'd love to grab it to incorporate into JonathanNeal's table

knows a bit

jgraham: Because when it came up before I remember you not knowing much.
Of course, you may have learnt since
Not really
Also, I have no idea what the contex is for the email you just sent
*context
See, you're cluelesss.
*clueless
The first case was more serpentine than clueless
paul_irish: The basic answer is there is no CSS file available for the UA stylesheet
(But you probably know taht already)
gsnedders: is there any way to get a dump of the CSS rules?

Hm, this was the case for IE too, but jon was able to extract the values from this nasty XML mess. regardless, if there is any opera resource for the default styling available.. i'd be great to document :)
MikeSmith: I can't think of any trivial way
I would think there'd be some userjs way to do it
realizes he can't actually spell oliver
guesses we have at least another four hours until olliej wakes up
(Call me cynical, but...)
hello again

It's not there to be found.

You don't get that with <video>s
More than halfway through capturing opera styles
Anyone able to summarize the Bug 7034 thread?

gsnedders: I think the summary is that nobody knows of a consistent set of rules for precisely determining authoring conformance criteria, and some people think there should be a consistent set of rules, and nobody can agree on what any of the rules should be
OK, that's the impression I got from the start of the thread
marks as read
and after about 120 emails, still nobody agrees on anything
(though the spec now lists some rough principles)
I'm vertifying the styles.
I have a few tests where if the reported styles are false, then changing a few things like colors and font sizes will produce new results.
I would love to add a stylesheet of w3c recommendations @ iecss
Huh? Why is HTMLAnchorElement.hash readonly in Safari?
http://www.googlefight.com/index.php?lang=en_GB&word1=Ian+Hickson&word2=Mike+Smith har
Your googlefight priveleges are revoked for failing to use quotes
I'm a bit confused what the RDFa+HTML activity is supposed to be, beyond rubberstamping RDFa 1.1 Core
as far as I'm concerned, the HTML+RDFa editor still has to substantively respond to bugs, if he wants it to be an HTML WG deliverable
othermaciej: Sure, but with "incompatible with deployed content" in the list of available answers, I don't have high hopes
Dashiva, ah come on!
Mike Smith still wins.
Dashiva: if the editor gives answers that a commenter objects to, then of course they are free to raise it as an issue, whatever the nature of the reason given
man, why are people suddenly all up in arms about changes that HTML_4_ made? (like getting rid of frames, font, etc)
did they run out of things in HTML5 to complain about?
Who's complaining?
JonathanNeal: How far did you get with trying to get a stylesheet for Opera?
people in www-style (about frames) and public-html (about everything under the sun, but more recently, not being allowed to use media-specific formatting features mixed in with their semantic markup)
gsnedders, http://www.iecss.com/ at the bottom is a link to the opera stylesheet.
along with firefox and webkit.
Hi TabAtkins!
Do you have a twitter?

Don't we have folks who work on Opera, Webkit, IE in this chan?
works at Opera
They should be able to say "no no no, you got that wrong, oooh you forgot this, ooooh good call didn't realize we had that in there"
We're mainly markup people here, though
What do we know about layout? :P

Well, there is now :)
